required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Injection Rate of Local Anesthetic in Caesarean Section
clinical_study.official_title: Does the Injection Rate of Local Anesthetic Affect the Onset of Sensory Block and Incidence of Hypotension in Caesarean Section

brief_summary.textblock: In the present study, we investigated the effects of two different injection rates of local anesthetic solution on the onset of sensory block, and the incidence and the onset of hypotension in pregnant women undergoing spinal anesthesia. A total of 67 patients were randomized into two groups: 120-second injection time (Group S; n = 33) and 15-second injection time (Group F; n = 34). Maximum level of sensory and motor block, time to sensory block at the level of T6, hemodynamic parameters, use of ephedrine and incidence of nausea and vomiting were recorded at different time points. Maximum level of the sensory block was similar. The time to achieve adequate and maximum sensory block level was shorter in Group S (p = 0.004 and 0.037, respectively). Incidence of hypotension was similar, but hypotension occurred earlier in Group F (p = 0.011). Requirement for ephedrine and incidence of nausea and vomiting was similar. This study showed that 120-second injection duration is associated with similar onset of the sensory block and slower onset of hypotension. We conclude that prolonging the duration of local anesthetic injection to 120-seconds is advantageous compared with 15-seconds.

detailed_description.textblock:
The anesthetist was blinded to the groups after the intrathecal administration of anesthesia and followed up with the patients and collected the data. After blocking was achieved, the patients were placed in the supine position, and the uterus was transported to the left by tilting the table 15° to the left. The level of the sensory block was evaluated by bilateral pinprick test, and the level of motor block was evaluated with the modified Bromage scale at 2-minute intervals in the first 15 minutes and at 5-minute intervals in the next 30 minutes after the spinal injection. When the level of the sensory block reached an adequate level (T6) the surgery was allowed to start. The patients whose block level did not reach T6 within 10 minutes were excluded from the study.
Considering the moment when the subarachnoid injection began as the onset time, the time to reach the T6 level, maximum sensory block level and motor block (Bromage scale 3) level were recorded in each patient. Motor block of the lower limbs was assessed using the Bromage scale (0 = ability to raise extended leg; 1 = inability to raise extended leg, ability to flex the knee; 2 = inability to flex the knee, ability to flex the ankle; 3 = inability to flex the knee and ankle).
The peak heart rate (HR) and systolic blood pressure (sBP) values of all patients were recorded before the procedure; immediately after spinal anesthesia; and at 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, and 45 minutes after the procedure. A decrease of systolic blood pressure (sBP) below 90 mmHg and more than a 30% decline in baseline blood pressure were considered as hypotension. Any hypotension was treated with boluses of 5 mg ephedrine each time until the systolic arterial pressure returned to normal ranges (> 90 mmHg and > 70% baseline value). In the patients who received ephedrine, the time of first ephedrine administration was considered as the time of first hypotension, and the total amount of ephedrine used was recorded. In addition, the local anesthetic injection rate (mL/s) for each patient was calculated as the ratio of local anesthetic injection volume (mL) to local anesthetic injection times(s) and recorded.
The sample size was calculated based on the T6 levels from a previous study (Singh SI. et al 2007). After setting the alpha error level at 0.05, beta error level at 0.20, effect size at 0.70, and difference in time at 0.9, the required sample size was determined as 26 for each group (slow and fast). By considering the potential data loss, we averaged the total sample size as 60 (30 patients for each group).

primary_outcome.description: The time to reach the sufficient sensory block and maximum level of sensory block was significantly shorter in Group S
The time to onset of hypotension was significantly shorter in Group F

intervention.intervention_name: Local anesthetic injection rate in spinal anesthesia
intervention.description: Administering intrathecal local anesthetics for all patients according to height and weight.

study_pop.textblock: The study included a total of 60 female patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists risk score (ASA) I-II risk status and singleton pregnancy aged between 18-40 years

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Anesthesiologists risk score (ASA) I-II risk status
- Singleton pregnancy aged
- Between 18-40 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women with contraindications for spinal anesthesia;
- Placental anomaly;
- Hypertension
- Cardiac disease
- Vascular disease
- Hepatic disease
- Renal disease
- Hemodynamic instability
- Spinal deformity;
- Severe mental retardation
- Weight < 50 kg or >110 kg; height < 140 cm or > 180 cm
- Metabolic and Acid-base balance disorders
- Emergency patients
